name: Kepler-397
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-397 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-397 is a star with 0.665 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.77 times its radius. It is located 3160.45 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-397 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-397 b

Kepler-397 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 22.25 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-397.

The mass of Kepler-397 b is 8.30 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-397 b is 2.46 that of Earth. At 8.30 Earth masses, Kepler-397 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-397 c

Kepler-397 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.48 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 135.50 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-397.

The mass of Kepler-397 c is 76.02 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-397 c is 6.18 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-397 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-397, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
